content.question: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. <math alttext="C D 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CD3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is a signaling protein that is typically found only in the plasma membrane of immune system T lymphocytes. <math alttext="C D 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CD3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is composed of several different polypeptides, including a gamma chain, <math alttext="C D 3 gamma" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CD3</mtext><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>γ</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. Scientists analyzed the promoter of the <math alttext="C D 3 gamma" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CD3</mtext><mi>γ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> chain gene for regulatory sequences that might have positive or negative effects on expression of the gene. The scientists cloned fragments of the <math alttext="C D 3 gamma" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>CD3</mtext><mi>γ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> gene that included the first transcribed nucleotides plus up to 789 nucleotides of upstream regulatory sequences into plasmids in which the gene for the firefly enzyme luciferase immediately follows the fragments. The plasmids were then introduced into a line of T lymphocytes (Figure 1), and the cells were allowed to grow for a short while. Because the regulatory sequences of the <math alttext="C D 3 gamma" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>CD3</mtext><mi>γ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> gene immediately precede the luciferase gene in the plasmids, the activity, either positive or negative, of the regulatory sequences affected the amount of luciferase gene expression by the T lymphocytes. Luciferase catalyzes a reaction that results in the release of light and is responsible for the bioluminescence (light flashes) of fireflies. By quantifying the bioluminescence, or luciferase activity, in the cells, the scientists were able to determine the effects of each <math alttext="C D 3 gamma" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>CD3</mtext><mi>γ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> gene fragment cloned into the plasmids (Figure 2) on expression of the gene. Figure 1. Summary of experimental procedure. A series of plasmids containing fragments of the <math alttext="C D 3 gamma" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>CD3</mtext><mi>γ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> upstream regulatory sequences cloned immediately before the luciferase gene were constructed. Each type of plasmid was introduced into T lymphocytes. The amount of luciferase produced by the lymphocytes was dependent on the regulatory sequences present in each plasmid. Figure 2. Analysis of the luciferase activity of T lymphocytes containing plasmids with different amounts of the <math alttext="C D 3 gamma" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>CD3</mtext><mi>γ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> regulatory sequence. Names of the plasmids are shown on the left. Included regulatory sequences and the resulting luciferase activity are shown on the right. Error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus 2 times the standard error of the mean" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. The transcription start site is indicated by <math alttext="plus 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>+1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Identify both the cellular component and the location of the component that is responsible for producing the luciferase protein from <math alttext="m R N A s" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNAs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> transcribed in the plasmid-containing T lymphocytes. Explain what dictates to the lymphocytes the correct order in which amino acids should be linked to form the luciferase protein.

frqParts.text: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. <math alttext="C D 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CD3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is a signaling protein that is typically found only in the plasma membrane of immune system T lymphocytes. <math alttext="C D 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CD3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is composed of several different polypeptides, including a gamma chain, <math alttext="C D 3 gamma" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CD3</mtext><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>γ</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. Scientists analyzed the promoter of the <math alttext="C D 3 gamma" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CD3</mtext><mi>γ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> chain gene for regulatory sequences that might have positive or negative effects on expression of the gene. The scientists cloned fragments of the <math alttext="C D 3 gamma" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>CD3</mtext><mi>γ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> gene that included the first transcribed nucleotides plus up to 789 nucleotides of upstream regulatory sequences into plasmids in which the gene for the firefly enzyme luciferase immediately follows the fragments. The plasmids were then introduced into a line of T lymphocytes (Figure 1), and the cells were allowed to grow for a short while. Because the regulatory sequences of the <math alttext="C D 3 gamma" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>CD3</mtext><mi>γ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> gene immediately precede the luciferase gene in the plasmids, the activity, either positive or negative, of the regulatory sequences affected the amount of luciferase gene expression by the T lymphocytes. Luciferase catalyzes a reaction that results in the release of light and is responsible for the bioluminescence (light flashes) of fireflies. By quantifying the bioluminescence, or luciferase activity, in the cells, the scientists were able to determine the effects of each <math alttext="C D 3 gamma" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>CD3</mtext><mi>γ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> gene fragment cloned into the plasmids (Figure 2) on expression of the gene. Figure 1. Summary of experimental procedure. A series of plasmids containing fragments of the <math alttext="C D 3 gamma" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>CD3</mtext><mi>γ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> upstream regulatory sequences cloned immediately before the luciferase gene were constructed. Each type of plasmid was introduced into T lymphocytes. The amount of luciferase produced by the lymphocytes was dependent on the regulatory sequences present in each plasmid. Figure 2. Analysis of the luciferase activity of T lymphocytes containing plasmids with different amounts of the <math alttext="C D 3 gamma" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>CD3</mtext><mi>γ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> regulatory sequence. Names of the plasmids are shown on the left. Included regulatory sequences and the resulting luciferase activity are shown on the right. Error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus 2 times the standard error of the mean" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. The transcription start site is indicated by <math alttext="plus 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>+1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Identify both the cellular component and the location of the component that is responsible for producing the luciferase protein from <math alttext="m R N A s" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNAs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> transcribed in the plasmid-containing T lymphocytes. Explain what dictates to the lymphocytes the correct order in which amino acids should be linked to form the luciferase protein.

(b) Identify the independent variable in the experiment described. Identify the plasmid that was used as a negative control for luciferase activity. Justify including the plasmid with the non-<math alttext="C D 3 y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>CD3</mtext><mi>γ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> active promoter in the experiments.

(c) Identify the plasmid that must contain the <math alttext="C D 3 y"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CD3</mtext><mi>γ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> core promoter sequence but the fewest or no negative regulatory sequences. Based on the data in Figure 2, describe the most likely cause of the variation in luciferase activity among the cells that contain plasmids <math alttext="p C D 3 gamma hyphen 419"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>pCD3</mtext><mi>γ</mi><mtext>-419</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="p C D 3 gamma hyphen 309"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>pCD3</mtext><mi>γ</mi><mtext>-309</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="p C D 3 gamma hyphen 239"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>pCD3</mtext><mi>γ</mi><mtext>-239</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="p C D 3 gamma hyphen 199"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>pCD3</mtext><mi>γ</mi><mtext>-199</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Calculate the approximate percent increase in luciferase activity between cells containing plasmid <math alttext="p C D 3 gamma hyphen 59"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>pCD3</mtext><mi>γ</mi><mtext>-59</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and cells containing plasmid <math alttext="p C D 3 gamma hyphen 149"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>pCD3</mtext><mi>γ</mi><mtext>-149</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Round to the nearest whole number.

(d) Predict the most likely observed level of luciferase activity if plasmid \(pCD3y-789\) is introduced into nonlymphoid cells such as a line of kidney tissue cells. Provide reasoning to justify your prediction.
